div.p: A BRIEF ACCOUNT OF A RELIGIOUS SCHEME, Taught and Propagated by a Number of EUROPEANS, who lately lived in a Place called NISQUEUNIA, in the State of NEW-YORK, but now re≈øiding in HARVARD, Commonwealth of MASSACHUSETTS, commonly called, Shaking Quakers.
By VALENTINE RATHBUN, MINISTER OF THE GOSPEL.

q.p: HE THAT IS FIRST IN HIS OWN CAUSE SEEMEST JUST: BUT HIS NEIGHOUBOUR COMETH AND SEARCHETH HIM.

div.p: TO WHICH IS ADDED, A DIALOGUE Between George Third of Great-Britain, and his Mini≈øters; giving an account of the late LONDON MOB, and the original of the Sect called SHAKERS.

WORCESTER: Printed in the Year 1782.

div.head: A BRIEF ACCOUNT, &c.
div.p: AT the earne≈øt reque≈øt of many enquiring minds, I have undertaken to pre≈øent to the publick, the matter, form and manner of a new and ≈øtrange religion, that has lately taken place among many people in the States of Ma≈ø≈øachu≈øetts and of New-York; and in pur≈øuing my purpo≈øe, I ≈øhall take the following method.
In the fir≈øt place, I will pre≈øent to view, the leaders and teachers of this new and ≈øtrange religion.
II. I will ≈øhew their manner of addre≈øs.
III. I will ≈øhew their doctrine, with the ≈øcripture evidence they bring to prove it.
IV. I will ≈øhew their manner of wor≈øhip.
V. I ≈øhall ≈øhew the directions which they give to tho≈øe that come to them, to be in≈øtructed.
VI. I will ≈øhew the power and effect of their in≈øtructions on their adherents.
VII. I ≈øhall ≈øhew what this new religion is, us pointed out by ≈øcripture te≈øtimony.
VIII. I ≈øhall give ≈øome rea≈øons for my knowledge in this new religion, not by mere ≈øpeculation, but by ≈øorrowful experience.
IX. I ≈øhall clo≈øe the whole by a word of advice to mini≈øters and people.
To return therefore according to my promi≈øe, in the fir≈øt place to pre≈øent to publick view, the leaders and teachers of this new and ≈øtrange religion.

The whole number con≈øi≈øts of five males and ≈øeven females; three of the males, and two females, profe≈øs to be perfect, or to have attained a ≈øtate of perfection; the other
≈øeven not perfect yet, but very far advanced. This people are Europeans, a part of which came from England to New-York in the year 1774, and lived at New-York and Albany, and places adjacent, two years‚Äîand in the year 1776, the re≈øt came to Philadelphia, and travelled through Penn≈øylvania to New-York, where the whole twelve came together, and directly went and made a purcha≈øe of land, in a place called Ni≈øqueunia, about nine or ten miles northwe≈øt from Albany, where they immediately ≈øettled, and went to clearing their land, and following their occupations of black≈ømithing, weaving and ≈øhoe-making and were unknown and unnoticed, unle≈øs by a few of their neighbours, until the 17th day of April 1780; at which time one Talmage Bi≈øhop brought tidings into New-Lebanon of a number of ≈øtrange and wonderful Chri≈øtians; the people, like the Athenians of old, were filled with define to ≈øee new things, and ran to ≈øee them. This brings me to ≈øhew,
II. Their manner of addre≈øs.

When any per≈øon goes to ≈øee them, they all meet him with many ≈ømiles, and ≈øeeming great gladne≈øs; they bid him welcome, and directly tell him they knew of his coming ye≈øterday. This ≈øets the per≈øon to wondering at their knowledge, and pre≈øently they get the per≈øon ≈øome victuals; then they ≈øit down and have a ≈øpell of ≈øinging; they ≈øing odd tunes, and Briti≈øh marches, ≈øometimes without words, and ≈øometimes with a minute of words known and unknown. After ≈øinging they fall to ≈øhaking their hands in a very extraordinary manner, with their eyes ≈øhut and face up; then a woman about forty years old ≈øits and makes a ≈øort of a prayer, chiefly in an unknown tongue (if I may ≈øo call it) then one of the men comes to the per≈øon, and pretends to interpret the woman's prayer; after which they tell the per≈øon the has come to the right place to be in≈øtructed; they enquire the per≈øon's name, and ever after call him by his Chri≈øtian name: They u≈øe no compliments, but their language is, Yea and nay. If the per≈øon have long hair, or a club, they bring the bible, and read to him 1 Cor. xi. chap. and 14th ver≈øe, then telling him if he intends to be in≈øtructed, he mu≈øt fir≈øt have his hair out ≈øhort; telling of his that he wears the mark of the bea≈øt.
If he con≈øents to have his hair cut, after it is done, they come round him, and touch him with their fingers here and there, and give him a fly cro≈øs, and in a very loving way, put their hands on his head, and then begin to preach their doctrine to him. But this leads me to enter on the third thing propo≈øed, viz.
III. To ≈øhew their doctrine, with the ≈øcripture evidence they bring to prove it.

They introduce their doctrine with a multitude of good words; ≈øaying, we mu≈øt hate ≈øin, love GOD, take up our cro≈øs, &c. Then proceed to ≈øay, in the fir≈øt place, that there is a new di≈øpen≈øation taking place, in which the ≈øaints ≈øhall reign a thou≈øand years with Chri≈øt, and that in that ≈øtate the ≈øaints ≈øhall be perfect, and that they have entered into it, and that they are the only church in the world; telling the per≈øon or hearer, that they have all the Apo≈øtolic gifts that were ever given; they tell the per≈øon that he has come to the right place for in≈øtruction, for they only are able to teach; then they pau≈øe a while to ≈øee how the per≈øon receives it, if they find he li≈øtens, and ≈øeems to be coming, they proceed and ≈øay, all the churches now in the world are antichri≈øt, and fal≈øe churches, and that there is not one per≈øon born again among them all, and that there has not one gone to Heaven for the≈øe twelve hundred years, no, not ≈øince the Apo≈øtolick age. If the per≈øon makes any objections, they tell him he mu≈øt not di≈øpute, his bu≈øine≈øs is to hear and receive in≈øtruction, and all hands will fall to confirming the truth of what is declared: This puts the per≈øon to ≈øilence, and then they proceed, with a great laugh, and tell him they have many things to ≈øay to him, which he is not yet able to bear; this is to engage to per≈øon to hear. Then, ≈øecondly, they proceed to ≈øay, that all external ordinances, e≈øpecially bapti≈øm and the Lord's ≈øupper, cea≈øed in the Apo≈øtolick age; and that God had never ≈øent one man to preach, ≈øince the Apo≈øtles days, until they entered into the new di≈øpen≈øation, and were ≈øent by God, from Great-Britain, to call in God's elect; and to confirm the truth of what the teacher has ≈øaid, he (the teacher) falls a trembling, and will ≈øay he feels the blood of Chri≈øt now running down his thigh and leg. Then they
tell the per≈øon the cannot bear any more now, but he mu≈øt come again very ≈øoon and they will tell him more; and thus they with many fawning embraces, part with him for that time.

3. When he comes again they meet him with great joy, cla≈øp him in their arms, and tell him they have the great love of God; and after things are a little ≈øettled, they begin with him again, telling him that he mu≈øt confe≈øs his ≈øins to them, from his childhood, that they may take his ca≈øe and travail for him, that he may be born again. If he be a profe≈ø≈øor of godline≈øs, and pleads that he hopes his ≈øins are forgiven, and wa≈øhed away by the blood of Chri≈øt; they tell him nay, they are not forgiven. They tell him what≈øoever is done in ≈øecret mu≈øt be revealed on the hou≈øe-top; and that they being the church, are the hou≈øe-top. Then one takes him alone, and if he confe≈ø≈øes his ≈øins to him, then he tells it to the re≈øt: But if it be ≈øu≈øpected he keeps back part of his ≈øin, he mu≈øt confe≈øs the whole all being pre≈øent.

4. They tell him they ≈øee angels, and conver≈øe with them, and hear them ≈øing, and ≈øing with them; and the ≈øpirits of ju≈øt men made perfect, they al≈øo freely conver≈øe with. They further tell him, the ≈øong that they ≈øing, is the ≈øong of the hundred and forty and four thou≈øand, which no man can learn, but only tho≈øe that are redeemed from the earth. Then tell him, they have got a mother pointing to a woman, one of their company: And that ≈øhe ≈øpeaks ≈øeventy-two tongues, and that when ≈øhe ≈øpeaks in unknown tongues, the living people cannot under≈øtand her; yet the dead under≈øtand her, for ≈øhe talks to them.

5. They proceed and ≈øay, the judgment is ≈øet, the books are opened, and the dead are now ri≈øing, and coming to judgment, and they are ≈øet to judge the world: Quoting 1 Cor. vi. chap. 2 ver≈øe. They tell the per≈øon, that the great tribunal is that church, and that the dead are coming before them every day, to be judged. They go on to ≈øay, all that have died in an imperfect ≈øtate, have gone to hell, or to a pri≈øon ≈øtate; and there to pay the debt to divine ju≈øtice by ≈øuffering; and that there are degrees of
puni≈øhment, which they are to pa≈øs through; great ≈øins, a great degree of hell, ≈ømall ≈øins, a ≈ømall hell: And after pa≈ø≈øing through the ≈øeveral degrees of puni≈øhment, and paying the whole debt, out they come, and ≈øtand before us (≈øay they) and are acquitted, and go home to Heaven; they quote for proof, P≈øal. xvi. 10. P≈øal. lxviii. 18. Ezekiel xvi. 44‚Äî61. 1 Peter iii. 18, 19, 20. 1 Peter iv. 6.

They comment on tho≈øe texts thus: Did Chri≈øt go to hell? Yes. When? Why when he was crucified. What did he go there for? Why to preach to the ≈øpirits in pri≈øon. What did he preach to them? Why the go≈øpel. Why did he preach the go≈øpel to the old world, or to the dead? Why that they might be judged, as unconverted ≈øinners, but finally live, according to God, in the ≈øpirit, after they have paid the debt in ≈øuffering.

6. They ≈øay, that the forecited woman, about forty years of age, is the woman ≈øpoken of in the xiith chapter of the Revelations of John, who was cloathed with the ≈øun, having the moon under her feet, and on her head a crown of twelve ≈øtars; and that ≈øhe has travailed and brought forth the man child. Further, that ≈øhe is the mother of all the elect; and that ≈øhe travail, for the whole world; and that no ble≈ø≈øing can come to any per≈øon, but only by and through her; and that in the way of her being po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of their ≈øins, by their confe≈ø≈øing of them, and repenting of the ≈øame, one by one, according to her direction.

7. They hold them≈øelves ≈øo far immortal, that they ≈øhall never die, but ≈øhall be changed in the twinkling of an eye, and go from this to the upper regions; and that now they are above all temptations and ≈øufferings, and can neither be lifted up or ca≈øt down; only as they ≈øuffer in travail for the elect. I might ≈øtill proceed much further on this head; but as it will nece≈ø≈øarily fall into their in≈øtructions to their adherents, I pa≈øs by it for the pre≈øent, and ≈øhall proceed.
IV. To ≈øhew their manner of wor≈øhip (if it may be ≈øo called.)

The manner and form of their wor≈øhip is entirely new
and different from all others: It differs but little on the Sabath, from any other day: They begin by ≈øitting down and ≈øhaking their heads in a violent manner, turning their heads half round, ≈øo that their face looks over each ≈øhoulder, their eyes being ≈øhut; while they are thus ≈øhaking, one will begin to ≈øing ≈øome odd tune, without words or rule; after a while another will ≈øtrike in; and then another; and after a while they all fail in, and make a ≈øtrange charm:‚ÄîSome ≈øinging without words, and ≈øome with an unknown tongue, or mutter, and ≈øome with a mixture of Engli≈øh: The mother, ≈øo called minds to ≈øtrike ≈øuch notes as makes a concord, and ≈øo form the charm. When they leave off ≈øinging, they drop off, one by one, as oddly as they come on; in the be≈øt part of their wor≈øhip, every one acts for him≈øelf, and almo≈øt every one different from the other; one will ≈øtand with his arms extended, acting over odd po≈øtures, which they call ≈øigns; another will be dancing, and ≈øometimes hopping on one leg about the floor; another will fall to turning round, ≈øo ≈øwift, that if it be a woman, her cloaths will be ≈øo filled with the wind as though they were kept out by a hoop; another will be pro≈øtrate on the floor; another will be talking with ≈øomebody; and ≈øome ≈øitting by ≈ømoaking their pipes; ≈øome groaning mo≈øt di≈ømally; ≈øome trembling extremely; others acting as though all their nerves were convul≈øed; others ≈øwinging their arms, with all vigour, as though they were turning a wheel, &c. Then all break off and have a ≈øpell of ≈ømoaking, and ≈øometimes great fits of laughter.‚ÄîThey have ≈øeveral ≈øuch exerci≈øes in a day, e≈øpecially on the Sabbath. When they go to eat, they ≈øit down, and have a ≈øpell of ≈øinging and ≈øhaking the head at the table, before they eat, ≈øome times they kneel down, ≈øhake their heads and groan, ≈øay nothing, and then fall to eating, and will be very merry and airy. If one has done eating before the re≈øt, he kneels down, ≈øhakes his head a ≈øpell, and off he goes and leaves the re≈øt eating; ≈øo each one di≈ømi≈ø≈øes the table for him≈øelf: But it is impo≈ø≈øible to point out any exact form; for they vary and differ, and ≈øeldom act the ≈øame form exactly over again. They chu≈øe ≈øo to do, to be ≈øingular,
left, as they ≈øay, they ≈øhould be connected with Babylon Every day their wor≈øhip is ≈øimilar to what has been ob≈øerved. They have no publick prayer, no preaching, and but little reading. Their actions in wor≈øhip is according to the dictates of the ≈øpirit that governs them; then they profe≈øs ≈øaying, they are in a ≈øpiritual di≈øpen≈øation.
Having thus ≈øhewn as far as may be, their manner of wor≈øhip, I proceed fifthly, to ≈øhew the directions which they give to tho≈øe that come to them to be in≈øtructed.

V. When any per≈øon goes to them to be in≈øtructed, they enquire of him, whether he has given his vote and money for the defence of the country, and pre≈øently tell him, it is contrary to the Go≈øpel to bear arms, ≈øaying Chri≈øt's kingdom is not of this world; they labour to convince him that it is a great error to have any thing to do with war and fighting: They directly tell him, he is not born again, and that he mu≈øt ob≈øerve their in≈øtructions, in order that he may attain to the new birth.‚ÄîThen they tell him, he mu≈øt confe≈øs his ≈øin to them; for if he hides his ≈øin they can do nothing for him: They further tell him, if he refu≈øes, they can tell him all his ≈øin that he ever committed; and pretend that he can keep nothing hid from them; and when they have frightened him to a confe≈ø≈øion, then they further tell him, he mu≈øt renounce and ab≈øtain from all the works of the fle≈øh; telling him, that the fir≈øt fall of our fir≈øt parents, was carnal copulation, and that this ruined the world; and that every one that has any thing to do with man or woman, in the work of generation, is acting Adam and Eve's ≈øin over again: They tell the man to ob≈øtain from his wife, the woman from her hu≈øband, and that if the wife doth not agree to it, the hu≈øband mu≈øt put her away; and if the hu≈øband will not agree to it, the wife mu≈øt leave her hu≈øband; and for an example, the mother, ≈øo called, will tell how ≈øhe left her hu≈øband, in New-York, and one of the men, how he left his wife in England. They tell young men and young women, if they marry, and have any thing to do with the works of lu≈øts of the fle≈øh, they can never be born again: They
≈øhew the nece≈ø≈øity of receiving this in≈øtruction by quoting Rev. iii 3, 4, 5. They dwell more on this part of their in≈øtructions than all the re≈øt. They tell their adherents, if they conform to their in≈øtructions in this point, there is no fear of their being born again; but if they di≈øobey, they certainly will be damned. While they are thus in≈øtructing their adherents, they ≈øometimes u≈øe great ≈øeverity, and ≈øometimes great flattery, to frighten on the one hand and allure on the other; and while they are thus at work with a per≈øon, they come round him, touch him with their fingers in different places, cro≈øs him here and there, get their hands on his head, and prophecy, that great ble≈ø≈øings are laid up for him: They pre≈øently make him believe them, and as ≈øoon as they ≈øee the ≈øpirit begin to operate on him, then they tell him, that now he has received the Holy Gho≈øt, and now if he di≈øobeys, it is a gone ca≈øe with him: They tell him, if he had never come to ≈øee them, and had died in his ignorance without receiving the Holy Gho≈øt, he would have gone to hell or a pri≈øon ≈øtate, and ≈øuffered a while, and then come out and gone to Heaven; but now, if he turns back, there is no forgivene≈øs, neither in this world, nor that which is to come: They quote for proof, Matt. xii. 32. This is to terrify the per≈øon, and bring him into an ab≈øolute dependence on them: Then they tell him, he mu≈øt come often to them to be in≈øtructed, or he will be in danger of being taken by evil ≈øpirits and led wrong; and that he mu≈øt not think he can under≈øtand the Bible, or know in any re≈øpect how to act, but only as he receives in≈øtruction from them: They tell him they have many things for him, which he is not yet able to bear; but as fa≈øt as he is able to receive it, they will in≈øtruct him: Thus the per≈øon is kept in con≈øtant expectation of ≈øomething new. If the per≈øon ≈øeems to be ≈øober, then one takes him by the hand, and round the floor with him, and make him run and ≈økip about, and laugh heartily at him, and will tell him he mu≈øt not be melancholy; and when they get him merry with them then let him go: Then they tell the per≈øon for his admiration, that ≈øince he has been
pre≈øent, they have had many of the dead come before them to be judged; and make him believe they know his thoughts, and know future events, and nothing can be hid from them; telling how people are together, and talking about them, and what they ≈øay, &c. Then they tell the per≈øon that they ≈øhall never die, and al≈øo all tho≈øe that obey them, and get to be perfect, ≈øhall never die, but be changed in a moment, and go home body and ≈øoul: But all the bodies of tho≈øe that die in their ≈øin, ≈øhall never ri≈øe.‚ÄîThey further tell him, that the hundred and forty and four thou≈øand, which were ≈øealed; twelve thou≈øand out of each tribe, is a work yet to be done; and that they are of the tribe of Benjamin, though the younge≈øt tribe, and la≈øt in the account, yet fir≈øt in the order, of being ≈øealed; and that they are the fir≈øt fruits of that tribe; and that all that are to be brought in, in America, will belong to that tribe: And thus, the la≈øt is to be fir≈øt, and the fir≈øt la≈øt.

I might ≈øtill proceed, on this head; but it would be endle≈øs to repeat all their in≈øtructions to their adherents, as they are ever ≈øtudying new things to keep up the dependence and admiration of their di≈øciples. I ≈øhall therefore pa≈øs on.
VI. To ≈øhew the power and effect of their in≈øtructions, on their adherents.

There is a very extraordinary and uncommon power attends their in≈øtructions; in the fir≈øt place, a total blindne≈øs, as to all their former views of religion and the Bible, on the in≈øtructed, takes place; and then a ≈øtrange infatuation of the mind, to believe all their teachers ≈øay. Pre≈øently a ≈øtrange power begins to come on, and takes place in the body, or human frame; which ≈øets the per≈øon to gaping and ≈øtretching; and ≈øoon ≈øets him to twitching, as though his nerves were all in a convul≈øion. I can compare it to nothing nearer in its feelings, than the operations of an electeri≈øing machine; the per≈øon believes it is the power of God, and therefore dare not re≈øi≈øt, but wholly gives way to it.‚ÄîThus the power comes on, more and more; and as the power increa≈øes, ≈øo their faith increa≈øes,
